```{r setup, include = FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)
library(plotly)

rockfall <- read_csv("~/Documents/Studium/Fachinhalte/5. Semester GB/Natural Hazards/Assesments/RockFallData_SLF.csv")
```

```{r plot, echo=FALSE}
rockfall_yearly <- rockfall %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  summarise(count = n(),
            volumeyear = sum(volume, na.rm = TRUE))
  
# 2. Skalierungsfaktor definieren
scale_factor <- 1e-6   # Volumen in Millionen m³

rockfall <- rockfall %>%
  left_join(rockfall_yearly, by = "year")

ggplot() +
  geom_line(data = rockfall_yearly, 
            aes(x = year, y = count), color = "blue") +
  geom_jitter(data = rockfall,
             aes(x = year, 
                 y = 22,               
                 color = permafrost),
             alpha = 0.5,
             size = 3,
             height = 0.9) +
  labs(
    title = "Rockfall frequency, volume and permafrost",
    x = "Year",
    caption = "Ploting: Tobias Tuchel. Data from: Permos 2025"
  ) +
  geom_col(data = rockfall_yearly,
           aes(x = year,
           y = volumeyear*scale_factor),
           fill = "grey",
           width = 0.8,
           alpha = 0.6)+
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Number of rockfalls",
    sec.axis = sec_axis(~./scale_factor,
                        name = "Yearly Rockfall Volume [m³]")
  )+
  theme_light()

```

# Climate Change {#climate-change}
Since the 19th century the climate of the european alps is changing dramatical. Temperature increased around 2 °C celsius and is expected to increase further (Fig. Y). The speed and intensity of climate change outpaces global warming (Dumont et al. 2025). That has multiple effects, especially on the cryosphere and hydrosphere. Frequency, location and magnitude of hazards in the rapid changing alpine environment are extremely sensitive to climate change (Mani 20121).
